facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 893 and 894 of 1964 are appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 22, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 304 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 893 and 894 of 1964. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated the August 22, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 304 of 1960.

facts.text: The respondent, M/s Straw Products Ltd., Bhopal, is a public limited company incorporated in the erstwhile State of Bhopal in 1939 and was given the certificate of commencement of business on May 30, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, M s Straw Products Ltd., Bhopal, hereinafter called the assessee, is a public limited companypany. It was incorporated in the erstwhile State of Bhopal in 1939 and was given the certificate of companymencement of business on May 30, 1939.

facts.text: On September 20, 1938, the assessee entered into an agreement with the Government of Bhopal.

anchor.surface_text: On September 20, 1938, the assessee entered into an agreement with the Government of Bhopal. Under the agreement the assessee obtained certain companycessions and facilities.

facts.text: Under the agreement, the assessee got exclusive licence to manufacture card-board articles of all kinds, land on lease on favourable terms, and was exempted from payment of customs and other duties payable to the municipality.

anchor.surface_text: Under the agreement the assessee obtained certain companycessions and facilities. The assessee number only got exclusive licence to manufacture card- board articles of all kinds but also got land on lease on favourable terms. It was also exempted from payment of customs and other duties payable to the municipality.

facts.text: Clause 8 of the agreement provided that during the period of 10 years from the date on which the Company takes over the land, the Company shall not be liable to pay any sum by way of taxation to the State, subject to certain conditions.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 8 of the agreement is relevant for the purpose of these appeals and is in the following terms Subject to and so far as the State shall number become or become obliged by any Instrument of Accession or Supplementary Instrument under the Government of India Act, 1935, in respect of any Federal Taxation, it is hereby agreed as follows- During the period of I 0 years from the date on which the said Company takes over the land for its business purposes the said Company shall number be liable to pay any sum by way of taxation to the State.

facts.text: It is common ground that the agreement was acted upon and for a period of 10 years the assessee was not called upon to submit any returns of income and no assessment was made on the assessee under the Bhopal Income Tax Act. This period expired on October 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that this agreement was acted upon and for a period of 10 years the assessee was number called upon to submit any returns of income and numberassessment was made on the assessee under the Bhopal Income Tax Act. This period of ten years expired on October 31, 1948.

facts.text: On August 1, 1949, Bhopal merged in India and was formed into a Chief Commissioners Province.

anchor.surface_text: On August 1, 1949, Bhopal merged in India and was formed into a Chief Commissioners Province.

facts.text: For the assessment year 1949-50, the assessee was assessed under the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922, on the total income of the period November 1, 1948 to December 12, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1949-50, the assessee was assessed under the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922, on the total income of the period November 1, 1948 to December 12, 1948, as the assessee made up its accounts on the 31st December each year.

facts.text: For assessment years 1952-53 and 1953-54 (previous years Calendar years 1951 and 1952), the Income Tax Officer by orders dated November 27, 1952 and September 30, 1953 allowed depreciation on the basis of the original cost paid in 1939.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment years 1952-53 and 1953-54, the assessment years which are the subject matter of this reference  previous years Calendar years 1951 and 1952, respectively , the Income Tax Officer, by orders dated November 27, 1952 and September 30, 1953, allowed depreciation on the machinery, buildings and other assets owned by the assessee on the basis of the original companyt, i.e., the companyt paid in 1939.

facts.text: Subsequently noticing a report in the Times of India dated March 15, 1957 giving the view of Bombay High Court in Dhrangadhra Chemical Works case, the ITO initiated action under s.34 for 1952-53 and 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently numbericing a report in the Times of India, dated March 15, 1957, giving the view taken by the Bombay High Court in the case of Dhrangadhara Chemical Works Limited 1 , the Income Tax Officer initiated action under S. 34 1  of the Act in respect of these two assessment years.

facts.text: ITO by order dated March 4, 1958 held that WDV as on 1-1-1951 to be redetermined by determining WDV as on 1-11-1948 under Bhopal Act, deduct all depreciation actually allowed till 31-12-1950.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the assessees objections, the Income Tax Officer by his order dated March 4, 1958, held that the written down value of the assets of the companypany will have to be redetermined as on 1-1-1951. This would be done by first determining the written down value of assets as on 1-11-1948 under the Bhopal Income Tax Act.

facts.text: Consequently, depreciation for 1952-53 reduced from Rs. 2,71,961 to Rs. 1,29,883 and for 1953-54 from Rs. 2,87,285 to Rs. 1,72,673.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the depreciation of Rs. 2,71,961 allowed in the original assessment for 1952-53 was reduced to Rs. 1,29,883 and for the assessment year 1953-54 the original depreciation allowance of Rs. 2,87,285 was reduced to Rs. 1,72,673.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal held no excess depreciation allowed, no basis for s.34 proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner, disagreeing with the Income Tax Officer, held on appeal that the assessee had number been allowed excess depreciation allowance as per the original assessment and there was numberbasis for initiating proceedings under s. 34.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal upheld the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal upheld the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and directed the companyputation of the allowance on that basis.

facts.text: High Court by judgment dated August 22, 1961 answered the question in favor of the basis adopted by AAC.

anchor.surface_text: On a reference the High Court by its judgment dated August 22, 1961, answered the question as follows In the circumstances of this case the companyrect basis for companyputing written down value of depreciable assets of the companypany is the one adopted by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: On August 20, 1962, Central Government made Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties Amendment Order, 1962 amending para 2 of 1949 Order retrospectively.

anchor.surface_text: On August 20, 1962, in exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 6 of the Taxation Laws  Extension to Merged States and Amendment  Act, 1949  LXVII of 1949  the Central Government made the following order to amend the Taxation Laws  Merged States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1949.

facts.text: The Explanation inserted deems 'all depreciation actually allowed under any laws or rules of a Merged State' to mean, in cases of exemption under agreement with Ruler, the depreciation that would have been allowed had income not been exempted.

anchor.surface_text: Explanation.-For the purpose of this paragraph, expression all depreciation actually allowed tinder any laws or rules of a Merged State means and shall be deemed always to have meant a   b in cases where income had been exempted from tax under any laws or rules in force in a Merged State or under any agreement with a Ruler, the depreciation that would have been allowed had the income number been so exempted.

facts.text: The Tribunal referred the question to High Court under s.66 of Indian Income Tax Act, 1929.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals by special leave are directed against the judgment of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh in a reference made to it by the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, under S. 66 1  of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1929, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: The question referred: Whether the correct basis for computing WDV as at 1-11-1948 is ITO's or AAC's, having regard to para 2 of 1949 Order and cl.8 of 1938 Agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court Whether, on the facts of the case and having regard to the provisions of paragraph 2 of the Taxation Laws  Merged States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1949, and clause 8 of the Agreement made on 20th September, 1938, between the assessee and the State of Bhopal, the companyrect basis for companyputing the written down value of the depreciable assets as at 1- 11-1948 is the one which is adopted by the Income Tax Officer or the one adopted by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner?

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeals, set aside High Court judgment, answered question in favor of ITO's basis applying 1962 Order.

anchor.surface_text: In companyclusion, applying the 1962 order to the facts of this ,case it is clear that the answer to the question referred must be that the companyrect basis for companyputing the written down value of the depreciable assets as on November 1, 1948, is the one which was adopted by the Income Tax Officer. In the result, the appeals are accepted, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the question answered as indicated above.

facts.text: Bhopal Income Tax Act applied, but no assessment due to exemption till Oct 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: This period of ten years expired on October 31, 1948. On August 1, 1949, Bhopal merged in India and was formed into a Chief Commissioners Province.

facts.text: Assessee made up accounts on 31st December each year.

anchor.surface_text: as the assessee made up its accounts on the 31st December each year.

facts.text: Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1949 came into force on December 3, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: as from December 3, 1949, when the Taxation Laws  Merged States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1949, came into force,

issues.text: Whether, on the facts of the case and having regard to the provisions of paragraph 2 of the Taxation Laws Merged States Removal of Difficulties Order, 1949, and clause 8 of the Agreement made on 20th September, 1938, between the assessee and the State of Bhopal, the correct basis for computing the written down value of the depreciable assets as at 1-11-1948 is the one which is adopted by the Income Tax Officer or the one adopted by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner?

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts of the case and having regard to the provisions of paragraph 2 of the Taxation Laws  Merged States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1949, and clause 8 of the Agreement made on 20th September, 1938, between the assessee and the State of Bhopal, the correc

issues.text: Whether the expression 'actually allowed under any laws or rules of a merged State' occurring in para 2 of the Taxation Laws Merged States Removal of Difficulties Order, 1949, meant allowable under the provisions of the said laws or rules or the allowance actually given effect to?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri, the learned counsel for the Revenue, urges before us that the High Court was wrong in answering the question in favour of the assessee. He urges that the expression actually allowed under any laws or rules of a merged State occurring in para 2 of the Taxation Laws  Merged States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1949, meant allowable under the provisions of the said laws or rules.

issues.text: Whether we are entitled to take into consideration the 1962 Order?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Desai, the learned counsel for the respondent, objects to this order being relied on by Mr. Sastri on various grounds. He further says that on a true interpretation of the order it does not apply to the case of the assessee. The question then arises whether we are entitled to take into consideration the 1962 order.

issues.text: Whether the 1962 Order is ultra vires or invalid?

anchor.surface_text: First he says that it is the first time that the order is being relied on in these proceedings and he is entitled to urge before us that the order is bad. He has given a number of reasons in support of his plea that the order is ultra vires, but in view of the decision of this Court in K. S. Venkataraman v. State of Madras, we refused to allow him to develop these objections.

issues.text: Whether the assessee's income had been exempted from tax under the agreement with the Ruler of Bhopal so as to fall within clause (b) of the Explanation to paragraph 2 of the 1949 Order as per the 1962 Order?

anchor.surface_text: He says that the words exempted from tax in the 1962 order mean that the assessee must have been liable to pay tax and then exemption granted. He points to the definition of the word assessee in the Bhopal Income Tax Act, 1936 VIII of 1936, which has been defined as a person by whom income tax is payable.

issues.text: Whether the 1962 Order applies retrospectively to the assessment years in question?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Desai then contends that the 1962 order is not retrospective and does not apply to assessments made before the order came into force. We see no force in this contention because the terms of the order are plain and if it is deemed, as directed by the order, that the expression actually allowed under any laws or rules of a merged State should have the meaning ascribed to it by the Explanation,

issues.text: Whether the question referred to the High Court is couched in terms of sufficient amplitude to cover the 1962 Order?

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, Mr. Desai contends that the question referred to the High Court in this case is not couched in terms of sufficient amplitude to cover the points he has tried to make, namely, whether the order dated August 22, 1962, is retrospective and whether the assessee is covered by the terms of cl. (b) of the Explanation.

arguments.claim: 'Actually allowed' is unambiguous and conveys allowance actually given effect to; requires deeming provision for fictional allowances

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to give such an artificial meaning to the expression all depreciation actually allowed under any laws or rules, and we agree with the High Court that the expression actually allowed is unambiguous and conveys the idea that the allowance was actually given effect to. If it was intended to include any allowances which are not actually allowed then the Central Government would have added a deeming provision

arguments.claim: Duty to apply retrospective amendment in tax reference if question wide enough and no new facts needed (following Bijli Cotton Mills)

anchor.surface_text: If the law which the Tribunal seeks to apply to the dispute is amended, so as to make the law applicable to the transaction in dispute, it would be bound to decide the question in the light of the law so amended. ... provided the question is couched in terms of sufficient amplitude to cover an enquiry into the question in the light of the amended law,

arguments.claim: Correct basis for WDV as on 1-11-1948 is ITO's, applying 1962 Order to facts

anchor.surface_text: In conclusion, applying the 1962 order to the facts of this case it is clear that the answer to the question referred must be that the correct basis for computing the written down value of the depreciable assets as on November 1, 1948, is the one which was adopted by the Income Tax Officer.

holdings.text: The correct basis for computing the written down value of the depreciable assets as on November 1, 1948, is the one which was adopted by the Income Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: In conclusion, applying the 1962 order to the facts of this ,case it is clear that the answer to the question referred must be that the correct basis for computing the written down value of the depreciable assets as on November 1, 1948, is the one which was adopted by the Income Tax Officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1962 Order retrospectively deems 'actually allowed' depreciation in exemption cases to include what would have been allowed if not exempted; applies to assessee's agreement under Bhopal Act; question wide enough per Bijli Cotton Mills.

holdings.text: The expression 'actually allowed under any laws or rules of a merged State' occurring in para 2 of the 1949 Order means the allowance actually given effect to, not merely allowable under the provisions.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to give such an artificial meaning to the expression all depreciation actually allowed under any laws or rules, and we agree with the High Court that the expression actually allowed is unambiguous and conveys the idea that the allowance was actually given effect to.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain and unambiguous textual meaning excludes fictional or deemed allowances without explicit deeming provision like in s.10(5) Explanation.

holdings.text: The Court is entitled to take into consideration the 1962 Order and must answer the reference in accordance with the amendment made by the order.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, following this judgment, we must hold that Mr. Sastri is entitled to rely on the 1962 order and it is our duty to answer the reference in accordance with the amendment made by the order, unless the question referred is not couched in terms of ,sufficient amplitude

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Bijli Cotton Mills: Tribunal/High Court/SC must apply retrospectively amended law to reference if question sufficiently wide and no new facts needed.

holdings.text: The respondent is not entitled to challenge the validity of the 1962 Order in these proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: but in view of the decision of this Court in K. S. Venkataraman v. State of Madras 1 , we refused to allow him to develop these objections.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per K.S. Venkataraman: cannot challenge validity of subordinate legislation exercising taxing powers in assessment proceedings; distinction rejected as order amends IT Act application.

holdings.text: The assessee's income had been exempted from tax under the agreement with the Ruler of Bhopal, falling within clause (b) of the Explanation to para 2 of the 1949 Order as amended.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to sustain this contention. The definition of assessee must mean a person by whom income tax is payable under the Bhopal Act. If it had not been for the agreement, the respondent would have been liable to pay tax and it is the agreement alone which exempted it from taxation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bhopal Act 'assessee' includes one liable but for exemption; agreement exempted what would otherwise be payable under Act.

holdings.text: The 1962 Order applies retrospectively to the assessment years 1952-53 and 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: We see no force in this contention because the terms of the order are plain and if it is deemed, as directed by the order, that the expression actually allowed under any laws or rules of a merged State should have the meaning ascribed to it by the Explanation, as from December 3, 1949,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order expressly deems expression 'always to have meant' the explained sense from date 1949 Order effective (Dec 3, 1949).

holdings.text: The question referred to the High Court is couched in terms of sufficient amplitude to cover the 1962 Order and its application.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, overrule Mr. Desais objection and hold that the question framed by the Appellate Tribunal is wide enough to include a discussion of the amendments made retrospectively in the Taxation Laws  Merged States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1949.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Question refers to para 2 of 1949 Order and facts; 'having regard to' not restrictive; includes retrospectively amended para 2.

precedents.cited_proposition: the written down value on the opening day of the account period for which assessment is to be made under the Indian Income Tax Act should be taken at the actual cost, less the depreciation which would have been claimed under the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: In conclusion, applying the 1962 order to the facts of this ,case it is clear that the answer to the question referred must be that the correct basis for computing the written down value of the depreciable assets as on November 1, 1948, is the one which was adopted by the Income Tax Officer.
In the result, the appeals are accepted, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the question answered as indicated above.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to give such an artificial meaning to the expression all depreciation actually allowed under any laws or rules, and we agree with the High Court that the expression actually allowed is unambiguous and conveys the idea that the allowance was actually given effect to.
In the result, the appeals are accepted, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the question answered as indicated above.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to sustain this contention. The definition of assessee must mean a person by whom income tax is payable under the Bhopal Act. If it had not been for the agreement, the respondent would have been liable to pay tax and it is the agreement alone which exempted it from taxation.
In the result, the appeals are accepted, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the question answered as indicated above.

anchor.surface_text: We see no force in this contention because the terms of the order are plain and if it is deemed, as directed by the order, that the expression actually allowed under any laws or rules of a merged State should have the meaning ascribed to it by the Explanation, as from December 3, 1949,
In the result, the appeals are accepted, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the question answered as indicated above.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, overrule Mr. Desais objection and hold that the question framed by the Appellate Tribunal is wide enough to include a discussion of the amendments made retrospectively in the Taxation Laws  Merged States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1949.
In the result, the appeals are accepted, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the question answered as indicated above.
